evidence.text: Plaintiff Shaleeta Boyd is an unhoused mother living at Camp Integrity... Plaintiff Amalia Mendoza is an unhoused women living at Camp Integrity... Plaintiff Floyd Barrow is an unhoused Navy Veteran living at Camp Integrity... Plaintiff Eddy Metz a senior suffering from chronic disabilities living at Camp Integrity... Plaintiff Christie Marie Cook is unhoused living with schizoaffective disorder... Plaintiff Anker Aardalen is unhoused man who is currently confined to wheelchair... Plaintiff Courtney Huff is a women who periodically lives at Camp Integrity because she is periodically displaced from her housing due to domestic violence and human trafficking... Plaintiff Jeff Grove is a resident of Camp Integrity who operates an impromptu cooling center... Plaintiff Donald Hensley is a resident of Camp Integrity who lost his home when the government destroyed the boat he was living... Plaintiff Brian Nelson is a resident of Camp Integrity who has saved several people from overdose... Plaintiff Camp Integrity is an unincorporated association of people and their property...

extracted.value: Plaintiffs are unhoused people living at Camp Integrity, including Shaleeta Boyd, Amalia Mendoza, Floyd Barrow, Eddy Metz, Christie Cook, Anker Aardalen, Courtney Huff, Jeff Grove, Donald Hensley, Brian Nelson, and Camp Integrity as an unincorporated association

evidence.text: On July 17th the City of San Rafael passed an ordinance the San Rafael Municipal Code §§19.50 and amending SMC §19.20.080(c) that redefined a criminally prosecutable offense of 'camping'... It defines camping as 'repetitiously ... consuming meals' or 'repetitiously ... possessing backpacks'... The infraction for violating these broad ordinances - that could be violated by having lunch - is a penalty of up to six months in jail and $500 fine.

extracted.value: City of San Rafael passed SMC §§19.50 and amended SMC 19.20.080(c) on July 17, 2023, to be implemented August 16, 2023, criminalizing 'repetitiously consuming meals' and 'repetitiously possessing backpacks' for unhoused people

evidence.source_document: Verified Complaint and Ex Parte Application for TRO and PI, Notice of Exparte Application for TRO and PI for Injunctive Relief to Halt Implementation of San Rafael Code 19.50 and SMC 19.20.080(c) on August 16th 2023
evidence.text: Based on information and belief, plaintiffs allege the following: Around June 2023, San Rafael Assistant City Manager Chris Hess, San Rafael City Manager Cristine Alliovich, San Rafael Police Chief David Spiller, San Rafael Director of Public Works April Mills communicated through a series meetings and electronic communications to discuss changing the City of San Rafael ordinances regulating the public use of property by people who are do not have housing and live outside... At the end of June, Hess, Alliovich, Spiller, and Mills came to an agreement among themselves about modifying City of San Rafael adding Chapter 19.50 to the city's municipal code... Chris Hess submitted that proposed amendment to Christine Alliovich, who approved it to be submitted to the City of San Rafael city council for ratification... Assistant City Manager and Director of Homeless Services Chris Hess said at the July 17 City Council meeting stated 'Between the date in which [the ordinance is adopted] and the time from when its implemented, we would begin right away with an education program for the homeless community involving all of our service, we would be providing notice about all of the new rules.'

extracted.value: City officials (Chris Hess, Cristine Alilovich, David Spiller, Amy Miller) discussed and approved the ordinance in meetings, but provided no meaningful clarification to the public

evidence.source_document: Verified Complaint and Ex Parte Application for TRO and PI, Notice of Exparte Application for TRO and PI for Injunctive Relief to Halt Implementation of San Rafael Code 19.50 and SMC 19.20.080(c) on August 16th 2023
evidence.text: SMC 19.50 and SMC 19.20.080(c) will Increase Drug Overdoses By 15-25% over the next 10 years, accounting for around 1-4 deaths of unhoused people who otherwise could have survived and gone on to secure permanent housing... SMC 19.50 and SMC 19.20.080(c) will Isolate Victims of Human Trafficking and Domestic Violence and Will Greatly Increase The Likliehood They Are Victims of Rape, Human Trafficking, and Other Forms of Violence... SMC 19.50 and SMC 19.20.080(c) will Destroy Camp Integrity, and Result in People Being Deprived of Bathrooms There, as well as food water and other necessities of life... If the Court Does Not Intervene Plaintiff Will Suffer Irreparable Harm, Including Injury and Death Caused by Complications To Severe Medical Conditions.

extracted.value: Ordinance will cause irreparable harm including increased drug overdoses (15-25% increase over 10 years), isolation of human trafficking/domestic violence victims, destruction of Camp Integrity's facilities, and denial of basic necessities

evidence.text: Jimmy Sanders intended on participating in this lawsuit, but died in his tent at Camp Integrity on July 29th. Jimmy was 'number 1 lumper' when he used to work unloading big rigs at the port of Oakland when he was a young man. After he was a victim of a catastrophic car crash caused by man fleeing from police, Jimmy became disabled which over the course of several years lead him into homelessness. He was kind, generous spirit and his death is both a loss for our community and for this action before the court. We remember and honor you Jimmy Sanders.

extracted.value: Jimmy Sanders, a plaintiff and 'number 1 lumper' at Oakland port, died in his tent at Camp Integrity on July 29, 2023, after becoming disabled from a car crash
